englishName: Alley of the Greeks, Castello District
historicalDescription: This area in the Castello district was known for its Greek population and Orthodox churches in the 15th century, as Venice had strong ties with the Byzantine Empire.

connection.historicalDescription: Located near Calle dei Greci in Castello, this bridge was named for the Byzantine merchants and craftsmen who settled in this area after the fall of Constantinople in 1453. The Greek Orthodox community maintained close ties to Byzantine traditions and established workshops nearby.

This bridge was named for its proximity to the Greek Orthodox church of San Giorgio dei Greci in Castello. The church was the religious center for the Greek community in Venice since the 16th century, and the bridge served as an important access point for worshippers.

This bridge in the Castello district near Calle dei Greci was named after the coppersmiths and boilermakers who maintained workshops in this area during the Renaissance. Many Greek artisans excelled in metalworking, contributing to Venice's reputation for fine craftsmanship.

Named for the merchants from the Eastern Mediterranean (known as Levantines) who frequented this area of Castello. Near Calle dei Greci, this bridge connected important trade routes where Greek, Turkish, and other Eastern merchants would conduct business with Venetian traders.

Located in Castello near the Greek quarter, this bridge was named after the Greek Orthodox confraternity (Scuola dei Greci) established in the 16th century. The confraternity provided social services and mutual aid to the Greek community, and members would cross this bridge to reach their meeting hall.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: This covered passageway near Calle dei Greci would have connected to the Greek Orthodox church of San Giorgio dei Greci, referencing the Greek community that had been granted permission to establish their own church in the 16th century.

This street would have led to the Greek community's school (scuola) where Greek language, theology, and culture were taught to preserve their heritage. The Greek community in Castello was highly educated and maintained strong cultural traditions.

Named after the prominent Greek-Venetian Flangini family who were wealthy merchants in the area. Tommaso Flangini, a notable family member, funded a Greek college in Venice during the Renaissance period, making significant contributions to Greek education in the Castello district.

This former canal, later filled in, would have referenced the Eastern Orthodox patriarchs who occasionally visited or maintained correspondence with the Greek community in Venice. The name honors the religious leadership connection between Venice and the Eastern Orthodox Church.

This small square would have been known for workshops of Greek icon painters who settled in the area. The Byzantine tradition of iconography was preserved by Greek artisans in Venice, many of whom lived and worked near Calle dei Greci in Castello.

This commercial street would have housed shops of merchants trading goods from the Eastern Mediterranean (Levant). Greek, Armenian, and other Eastern traders established businesses here, importing spices, silks, and other luxury goods from Constantinople and beyond.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of Saint Nicholas of the Greeks
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A paved street dedicated to Saint Nicholas, highly venerated in the Eastern Orthodox tradition and particularly important to Greek sailors and merchants. This would have been one of the more prestigious streets in the Greek quarter of Castello.

This street likely housed scribes and scholars who worked with Greek manuscripts. Following the fall of Constantinople in 1453, many Byzantine scholars fled to Venice, bringing valuable manuscripts and establishing workshops to preserve Greek literary traditions in the Castello district.

Named after a metochion (a dependent monastery or religious representation) that would have served as a Venetian embassy of Mount Athos or another major Eastern Orthodox monastic center. These religious outposts facilitated cultural and religious exchanges between Venice and the Orthodox East.
